Chapter 5, Part 2: Distinguishing Latent Tendencies. Those sentient beings whose latent tendencies increase in dependence on this matter are bound to this matter.
It should be explained: In the past, present, and future, which latent tendencies are able to bind which matters?
Verse:
If, in this matter, greed, ill-will, and pride have not yet been eliminated,
If in the past or present they have already arisen, in the future they are mental omnipresent factors.
The five [latent tendencies] can arise in their own time; those that do not arise are also omnipresent.
The rest are omnipresent in the past and future; in the present, they bind by directly perceiving.
Discussion:
Moreover, latent tendencies are generally of two kinds:
First, specific characteristics, namely greed, ill-will, and pride;
Second, common characteristics, namely views, doubts, and delusion.
Although there are many matters, this explains what is bound.
As appropriate, those not yet eliminated flow to the next section.
If there is craving, hatred, or pride in a given thing, and it has already arisen in the past and has not yet been eliminated, or if it has already arisen in the present, it binds this thing.
Because craving, hatred, and pride are passions of specific characteristics, and not all sentient beings necessarily generate them universally.
If the three of craving, hatred, and pride associated with mental consciousness in the future universally occur in the three time periods, they are all able to bind.
If the craving and hatred associated with the five consciousnesses in the future have not been eliminated and are able to be born, they only bind the future time period.
If the craving and hatred associated with the five consciousnesses in the future have not been eliminated and are unable to be born, they are also able to bind the three time periods.
The remaining views, ignorance, and doubt, whether past or future, when not yet eliminated, universally bind the three time periods.

Because these three are passions of general characteristics, and all sentient beings are universally bound by them.ğŸ”½When they are in the present, and are actually taking an object, they are able to bind this thing, according to the case.
It must be explained whether things of the past and future really exist or not, in order to discuss their binding.
If they really exist, then because all conditioned forces would always exist, they should be said to be permanent.
If they really do not exist, how can one speak of their bonds, their being bound, and their being freed?

The VaibhÄá¹£ikas definitely maintain that they really exist, but they say that these conditioned forces are not called permanent because they are combined with the various characteristics of conditioned dharmas.
In order to clarify this point, we must briefly set forth the basic doctrine and reveal the principle.
A verse says:
The three times exist because of the teaching, because of the existence of objects and results,
And because of the teaching of the three times, we admit the teaching of the existence of all dharmas.
The treatise says:
The three times really exist.
Why is this?
Because the World-Honored One has said so in the scriptures.
That is to say, the World-Honored One has said:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that if past form did not exist, the assembly of noble students with much learning would not diligently cultivate detachment from past form.
Because past form exists, the many-heard noble disciples should diligently abandon past form.
If future form does not exist, the many-heard noble disciples should not diligently cut off and seek future form.
Because future form exists, the many-heard noble disciples should diligently cut off and seek future form.
Moreover, because consciousness arises only when two conditions are present, as a scripture says:
Consciousness arises from two conditions.
What are the two?
Namely, the eye and form.
Extending to the mind and all dharmas.
If the past and future do not really exist, the consciousness that cognizes them should lack two conditions.

Having already used the holy teachings to prove the existence of the past and future, we will now use correct principles to prove the existence of the past and future, because when consciousness arises, there must be an object.
That is to say, only when there is an object can consciousness arise; without it, it does not arise. This principle is certain.
If the substance of the future and past does not really exist, then there would be consciousness without an object, and because the object does not exist, consciousness would also not exist.

Also, because there is a future effect of past action, that is, if the substance of the past does not really exist, then the future effect of good and bad action would not exist, because at the time the effect is born, the present cause does not exist.
For this reason, the VaibhÄá¹£ikas definitely establish the real existence of the two time periods of past and future.

If one claims to be a member of the SarvÄstivÄda school, one must definitely admit that the past and future exist as real entities, because it is said that the three time periods all definitely exist as real entities, and thus one is considered a member of the SarvÄstivÄda school.
That is, if a person says that the three time periods exist as real entities, then he is considered a member of the SarvÄstivÄda school.

If a person only says that the present time period exists as a real entity, and past action that has not yet yielded its effect exists as a real entity, but the future and past action that has already yielded its effect do not exist as real entities, then he can be considered a member of the VibhajyavÄda school, but he is not included in this school.
How many differences are there in this school?
Who established the best and most reliable theory of time?
Verse:
There are four kinds of theories: category, characteristic, state, and dependence.
The third, based on function, is the best theory of time.
Commentary:
Venerable DharmatrÄta says:
Time is different due to the difference in categories.
He says that when dharmas move through time, they have different categories but not different substances.
It is like when a gold vessel is destroyed and made into another object, the shape is different but the substance is not different.
Also, when milk turns into yogurt, it loses taste and potency, but not its color.
In the same way, when dharmas move through time, from the future to the present, from the present into the past, they only lose and gain categories, not substance.
Venerable Subhagupta says:
Time is different due to the difference in characteristics.

They say that when dharmas move through time, the past is only combined with the characteristic of the past, but it is not said to be separated from the characteristics of the present and future.ğŸ”½The future is only combined with the characteristic of the future, but it is not said to be separated from the characteristics of the past and present.
The present is only combined with the characteristic of the present, but it is not said to be separated from the characteristics of the past and future.
It is like a man who is only attached to one wife, but it is not said that he is not attached to the other concubines.
The Venerable Vasumitra says:
The three times are different due to different states.
They say that when dharmas move through time, they are said to be different in each state they reach, but they are different in state, not in substance.
It is like moving a single tally stick, calling it one when placed in the ones, a hundred when placed in the hundreds, and a thousand when placed in the thousands.
The Venerable BodhyÄyaá¹‡a says:
The three times are different due to different relations.
They say that when dharmas move through time, they are given different names in accordance with their prior and subsequent states, just as one woman is called a daughter and also a mother.
Of these four theories, the first, because it holds that dharmas are transformed, should be placed in the ranks of the heretical SÄá¹ƒkhya school.
The second theory is confused about the characteristics of the three times, because all three times have the characteristics of the three times.
When a person is presently lustfully attached to his wife, he only possesses lust for other women,
but he does not presently lust after them. What is the same about these two states?
The fourth theory holds that prior and subsequent states are mutually dependent, and therefore the three times should exist in any single dharma.
That is, prior and subsequent moments in the past are called past and future, and the middle one is present.
The same is true of the future and present.

Therefore, of the four theories, the third is the best, because it distinguishes the three times on the basis of differences in the activity of dharmas. The three times are distinguished on the basis of differences in activity.

They say that dharmas that have not yet performed their activity are called future, those that are performing their activity are called present, and those that have already ceased performing their activity are called past. They are not different in substance.
This has already been fully understood.
They should further explain: if the past and future also really exist, they should be called present. What do you call past and future?
Isn't it said in the previous statement that they are established based on activity?
If so, the present eye and other faculties included in the same category have what kind of activity?
How can they not be able to take effects and give effects?
Then past similar causes and so on, since they can give effects, should have activity.
They have half the activity, and the characteristics of the world would be mixed up.
Having briefly investigated, we will now refute in detail.
The verse says:
What obstructs activity and how?
If there is no difference in the world, it would be destroyed. Who has not yet arisen and ceased?
The nature of this dharma is very profound.
The treatise says:

You should explain how if the substance of a dharma is eternal, it should always be able to generate activity. What power of obstruction can make the substance of a dharma sometimes generate activity and sometimes not?
If you say that the noncombination of conditions is the obstruction, this is unreasonable, because you admit that the substance of a dharma is eternal.
Moreover, how can you say that activity is past, future, or present?
Can you further establish another activity in activity?

If this activity is not past, future, or present, and yet you say that activity exists, then it must be unconditioned and therefore eternal and not nonexistent. Therefore you cannot say that activity has already perished or that it has not yet occurred.
If you admit that activity is different from the substance of a dharma, you may incur this error, but it is not different, and therefore you cannot say that this error exists.
If that is so, your interpretation of the meaning of time is destroyed, because if activity is identical with the substance of a dharma, and the substance is eternal, activity also should be eternal.
How can you sometimes call it past or future?
Therefore the meaning of the three time periods established by them is not established.
Why is it not established?
Because conditioned dharmas that have not yet arisen are called future, those that have arisen but not yet ceased are called present, and those that have ceased are called past.
They should further explain: If, like present dharmas, the substance of past and future dharmas really exists, who has not yet arisen?
And who has already ceased?
It is said that the substance of conditioned dharmas always exists. How can it be established as not yet arisen or already ceased?
What was lacking before?
Because it did not yet exist, it is called not yet arisen.
What is lacking again later?
Because it has already ceased to exist, it is called already ceased.

Therefore, if one does not admit that dharmas were non-existent before and exist now, and exist now but will be non-existent again, then the meaning of the three time periods should not be established in any way.
However, what they say is that because it always combines with the characteristics of conditioned dharmas,
the impermanence of conditioned activities is merely empty words, because the principle of arising and ceasing does not exist.
To say that the substance of dharmas always exists but their nature is impermanent is something that has never been said before.
Based on this meaning, there is a verse that says:ğŸ”½Allowing that the substance of dharmas always exists,
But saying their nature is impermanent,ğŸ”½The nature and substance are also not separate,
This is truly the work of a sovereign.
As for what they say, Because the World-Honored One said so, the two past and future existences truly exist, we also say that the past and future exist.
This means that in the past there was once existence, and in the future there will be existence, because there are causes and effects.
Based on this meaning, it is said that the past and future exist, not that the past and future truly exist.
Who says that they exist like the present world?
If not like the present world, how do they exist?
They have the self-nature of the two past and future worlds.
This should be further questioned:ğŸ”½If they both exist, how can it be said that they exist because of the past and future natures?
It is only based on the two natures of cause and effect in the past and future, not on their truly existing substance.

The World Honored One, in order to avoid the view of slandering cause and effect, spoke of the existence of past and future based on the meaning of once having been and being about to be, because the word existence generally indicates both existent and nonexistent things.
It is like saying in the world that a lamp once did not exist and a lamp will not exist later.
Also, it is like saying:
The lamp has already gone out, not that I am now extinguishing it.
The meaning of speaking of the existence of past and future should also be like this.
If it were not so, the nature of past and future would not be established.
In that case, why did the World Honored One, based on that staff-knotted non-Buddhist, speak of karma that is past, exhausted, ceased, and transformed, yet still exists?
How could he not allow that karma once had a nature of existence?
Yet now the World Honored One again speaks of its existence, secretly speaking of it as existing based on the ability to produce results in the present continuity that it has attracted.
If it were not so, how could that past karma, which actually has the nature of existence, be past?
Reason necessarily must be so.
Because the Blessed One said in the SÅ«tra on the Emptiness of Ultimate Reality:
When the eye faculty is born, it does not come from anywhere, and when the eye faculty ceases, it does not accumulate anywhere.
It did not exist previously, but now it does. Having existed, it will not exist again.
If the past and future eye faculties really exist, the scriptures should not say that they were nonexistent previously.
If it is claimed that these words refer to the present, this refutation is unreasonable, because the nature of the present is not different from the substance of those past and future eye faculties.

If it is admitted that the present did not exist previously but now does, and having existed will not exist again, then the meaning that the past and future eye faculties have no substance is already established.
Again, what they say, that consciousness arises only when two conditions are present,

we should investigate together. When mind and mental objects are the conditions for the arising of mental consciousness, do mental objects act as the productive condition for mental consciousness in the same way that mind does?
Or do mental objects merely act as the object-support condition?
If mental objects act as the productive condition for mental consciousness in the same way that mind does, how can those mental objects that will exist a hundred thousand kalpas in the future,
or that will never exist, act as the productive condition for the arising of present consciousness?
Moreover, it is not reasonable to establish nirvana, which is contrary to all arising, as that which gives rise to things.
If a dharma can only be the object of perception, I say that the past and future are also objects of perception. If they do not exist, how can they be objects of perception?
I say they exist, just as they become objects of perception.
How do they become objects of perception?
It is said that they once existed and will exist.
When one recollects past form and feeling, etc., it is not as if one clearly sees them as existing in the present, but rather one recalls the characteristics of their once having existed;

retrospectively observing the future as existing is also like this. That is to say, just as one experiences form in the present, one retrospectively recollects the past as having existed in this way; just as one will experience form in the present, one prospectively observes the future as existing in this way.
If it were as if it existed in the present, it would have to be the present.
If it does not exist in the present, then one must admit that there is consciousness that has a nonexistent object, and the principle is thereby established.

If you say that past and future dharmas are in a state of dispersion and do not exist in the present, this is not reasonable, because when one grasps their characteristics, they are not in a state of dispersion.
Also, if these dharmas exist in the same way as the present, with only dispersion of atoms as a difference, then the substance of the atoms of form would be eternal.
Also, form would only be a dispersion or aggregation of atoms, and there would be no part that could be said to be born or destroyed.
This would be to follow the treatises of the heretical PÅ«raá¹‡a KÄÅ›yapa and to abandon the scriptures spoken by the Well-Gone One.
As a scripture says:
When the eye faculty is born, it does not come from anywhere. And so on at length. Also, it is not that feeling, etc. are aggregated from atoms.
How can it be said that past and future are in a state of dispersion?
However, when one recollects and looks back on feeling, etc., it is also as it was when it was not yet extinguished and had already been born.

If it exists as it does in the present, its substance should be eternal. If its substance does not exist in the present, then one should again admit that there is consciousness that has a nonexistent object, and this principle is also established by itself.

If the object of consciousness is completely nonexistent, then the thirteenth place should be the object of consciousness, since there are those who understand the nonexistence of the thirteenth place.
What is the object of this consciousness?
If you say that it takes the name as its object, then you should deny that the name is nonexistent.
Moreover, if the sound that previously did not exist is the object, what is the object of this consciousness?
If you say that it takes the sound as its object, then one who seeks the nonexistence of sound should make a sound again.
If you say that the nonexistent sound abides in the future state, how can you say that it does not exist, since the future really exists?
If you say that the past and future do not exist in the present, this is also unreasonable, because their essence is one.
If there is a slight difference in essence, then the principle of nonexistence before and existence now is established by itself.
Therefore consciousness generally takes as its objects both existent and nonexistent things.

However, when the bodhisattva says that it is impossible for the world to know or see what does not exist, he means that others, harboring conceit, also manifest the appearance of existence in what does not exist. I only consider what exists to be existent.
If it were otherwise, then all cognitions would have an object. What is the reason that one can have doubt or distinctions regarding an object?
This must necessarily be so.
Because the Blessed One said elsewhere:
Welcome, bhiká¹£us!

If you can be my disciples, without deceit, without deception, with faith and diligence, I will teach you in the morning, causing you to attain excellence in the evening, and I will teach you in the evening, causing you to attain excellence in the morning.
Then you will know that existence is existence, non-existence is non-existence, that which has a superior is that which has a superior, and that which has no superior is that which has no superior.
Therefore, their statement that because consciousness has an object, past and future exist, is also not a valid reason.
Moreover, their statement that past and future exist because karma has results is also unreasonable.
The SautrÄntikas do not say that past action is able to produce a future result. Rather, they say that a transformation of the series of dharmas projected by the action produces the future result.
This will be discussed in detail in the chapter on the self.
If you insist that past and future really exist, then the substance of the result must always exist, and what function can action have with regard to that result?
If you say that it can produce it, then the result produced must have been nonexistent and now become existent, and your theory is thereby proven to be false.
If all dharmas exist at all times, then what dharma has the power to produce what other dharma?
You would also be proving what non-Buddhists believe, namely, that the SÄá¹ƒkhya SÅ«tra says,
â€œThat which must exist always exists, and that which must not exist never exists.
That which must not be produced is never produced, and that which must cease never endures.â€
If you say that action can cause a result to become present, how does it cause the result to become present?
If you say that it causes the result to be brought to another place, then the result that is brought must always exist.
Moreover, how can formless dharmas be drawn in?
Moreover, that which is drawn in should originally be nonexistent.
If it is said that it only causes the substance to have a difference, the principle that it originally did not exist but now does is naturally established.
Therefore, this statement by the SarvÃ¢stivÄda school, if it says that past and future really exist, is not a good statement within the holy teachings.
If one wishes to state well that everything exists, one should state it as it is stated in the sÅ«tras.
How does the sÅ«tra state it?
As a sÅ«tra says:
Brahmin, you should know that everything that exists is only the twelve sense bases or only the three times.
As it exists, it is said to exist.

If past and future do not exist, how can it be said that there is that which can bind and that which is bound, as well as that which is untied?ğŸ”½Because the cause that gives rise to it, the latent afflictions, exist, it is said that the past and future afflictions that can bind exist.
Because the latent afflictions that take it as their object exist, it is said that the past and future bound events exist.
If the latent afflictions are eliminated, it is called being untied.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
Past and future exist in reality.
Those who love themselves should understand that the nature of dharmas is very profound and not the object of conjecture. How can one say that it does not exist just because one cannot explain it?
Because there is a different mode, this arises and this ceases, that is, the arising of form and so on is precisely the cessation of form and so on.
Because there is a different mode, different arising and different cessation, that is, the arising in the present world is the cessation in the future world.
Because there is a different mode, the present world is called arising, because when it is just arising it is included in the present world.
Because there is a different mode, it is said that the present world has arising, because there are many moments in the future world.
The subsidiary discussion is now complete. We should now consider whether when a matter is already cut off, its bonds are also severed?
If a matter is severed, are its bonds already cut off?
If a matter is severed, its bonds are certainly already cut off. But there are matters whose bonds are already cut off but which are not severed.
What is the matter of cutting off without severing?
In verse it is said:
As for the remaining pervasive latent afflictions that are to be eliminated by seeing suffering,
and the remaining objects that are still bound to it, even though the afflictions of the previous category have already been eliminated.
The treatise says:

In the stage of the path of seeing, when the knowledge of suffering has already arisen but the knowledge of accumulation has not yet arisen, the various [afflictions] to be eliminated by seeing suffering have already been eliminated, but if the pervasive latent afflictions to be eliminated by seeing accumulation have not yet been permanently eliminated, then those that can take this [knowledge of suffering] as their object are still bound to it.
And in the stage of the path of cultivation, no matter which path arises,

among the nine categories of objects, if the afflictions of the previous categories have already been eliminated but the remaining categories have not yet been eliminated, then the latent afflictions that can take this [path] as their object are still bound to it.
[This is] elimination but not disjunction. One should understand it in this way.

How many latent afflictions increase in relation to how many objects?ğŸ”½If one answers separately according to each object, it would require a great deal of discussion. Therefore, one should compose a brief VibhÄá¹£Ä. By this, although one expends only a small amount of effort, one can cross over a great flood of questions.
Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Although dharmas are numerous, they are briefly divided into sixteen kinds, namely the three realms, the five classes of dharmas, and pure dharmas.
The number of consciousnesses that can take them as objects is also the same.
One should simply understand which dharmas are the objects of which consciousnesses, and it is easy to think about which things are increased by which latent afflictions.
Here, one should first understand which dharmas are the objects of which consciousnesses.
Verse:

If the dharmas eliminated by seeing suffering, origin, and cultivation are bound to the desire realm,ğŸ”½They are the objects of three consciousnesses of their own realm and one of the form realm, and of the pure consciousness.
The form realm is the objects of three of its own realm and the lower realms, and of the pure consciousness of the upper realm.
The formless realm is the objects of the three realms, and of the three pure consciousnesses.
The dharmas eliminated by seeing cessation and the path increase the activity of their own consciousnesses.
The pure [dharmas] are the objects of the last three pure consciousnesses in the three realms.
Discussion:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

If the object is a dharma of the realm of desire, it is the object of five consciousnesses, i.e., the three of oneâ€™s own realm as explained above, plus the one of the realm of form, i.e., that eliminated by the path of cultivation, and the pure fifth, because they are all able to take it as an object.

If the object is a dharma of the realm of form, it is the object of eight consciousnesses, i.e., the three of oneâ€™s own realm as explained above, plus the one of the upper realm, i.e., that eliminated by the path of cultivation, and the pure eighth, because they are all able to take it as an object.

If the object is a dharma of the formless realm, it is the object of ten consciousnesses, i.e., the three of the three realms as explained above, and the pure tenth, because they are all able to take it as an object.
It should be understood that the dharmas eliminated by the paths of insight into cessation and path are each increased by one consciousness as a possible perceiver.
What does this mean?

If the object is a dharma of the realm of desire eliminated by the path of insight into cessation, it is the object of six consciousnesses, i.e., the first five as above, plus the sixth, which is increased by that eliminated by the path of insight into cessation.
Those eliminated by the path of insight are the objects of the six consciousnesses. The first five are as above, and the sixth increases by adding those eliminated by the path of insight.
Those eliminated by the paths of insight into the truths of cessation and path in the realm of form and the formless realm are objects of nine consciousnesses, as appropriate.

Pure dharmas are objects of ten consciousnesses, that is, the last three classes of the three realms, that is, those eliminated by the paths of insight into the truths of cessation and path and by cultivation, plus the pure tenth consciousness, because they are all capable of being objects.
In order to include the above meanings, we again compose a verse:
Those eliminated by insight into the truths of suffering and accumulation, and by cultivation, in the realms of desire, form, and no form,
Should be known as objects of five, eight, and ten consciousnesses, respectively.
Those eliminated by the paths of insight into the truths of cessation and path increase by adding the consciousness of their own realm as objects.
It should be known that pure dharmas are objects of ten consciousnesses.
Having understood that the sixteen kinds of dharmas are objects of the sixteen consciousnesses, we should now consider what things are increased by what proclivities.
If we were to discuss this in detail, the text would be too long, so we will only give a brief indication here.
There is a question:
How many latent afflictions increase in the presence of the faculty of pleasure?
It should be observed that the faculty of pleasure is generally of seven kinds: one in the desire realm, which is eliminated by cultivation, five in the form realm, and the undefiled seventh.
All the undefiled are not increased by any latent afflictions, as has been explained before.
Among these, the first six, as appropriate, are increased by the latent afflictions eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm and by the universal [afflictions] in the form realm.
If there is a question:

How many kinds of latent afflictions increase in the consciousness that takes the faculty of pleasure as its object?ğŸ”½It should be observed that this consciousness is generally of twelve kinds: the four in the desire realm, excluding that eliminated by seeing cessation, the five in the form realm, the two in the formless realm, namely that eliminated by seeing the truth of the path and that eliminated by cultivation, and the undefiled twelfth, all of which are able to take the faculty of pleasure as their object.

These are increased by the latent afflictions eliminated in the desire realm, as appropriate, by the conditioned [afflictions] in the form realm, by the two categories in the formless realm, and by the universal [afflictions].
If someone asks again:
How many kinds of latent afflictions increase in the consciousness that takes the faculty of pleasure as its object?

It should be observed that this consciousness generally has fourteen kinds. In addition to the previous twelve, two more are added, namely, those eliminated by seeing the truths of suffering and accumulation in the formless realm.

In this way, the fourteen kinds of consciousness can take the faculty of pleasure as their object. As appropriate, the latent afflictions of the desire and form realms are as mentioned above, while those of the four categories in the formless realm increase.
Based on this method, the rest should be considered.
If the mind is said to have latent afflictions because of them, do they definitely increase in this mind?

This is not definite. There may be latent afflictions that are associated with the mind, and those that take the mind as their object have not yet been eliminated. If associated with those that have already been eliminated, they do not increase.
Based on this meaning, it should be said in this way.
The verse says:
There are two kinds of minds with latent afflictions, namely defiled and undefiled.
Defiled minds include both, while undefiled ones are only subject to increase.
The treatise says:
Minds that are accompanied by the seeds of the passions are of two kinds: defiled and undefiled, because of the difference of their natures.

Among them, defiled minds may or may not increase the seeds of the passions. That is, if the seeds of the passions are associated with the mind and have not yet been eliminated, they increase. If the seeds have been eliminated, they do not increase, but they are still said to be accompanied by the seeds of the passions because they are always associated with the seeds.
If the mind is undefiled, the seeds of the passions only increase.

The seeds of the passions that are its objects have not yet been eternally eliminated, because it is only on the basis of the increase of the seeds of the passions that one is said to be accompanied by the seeds of the passions.

translated: In the above discussion of the ten passions, what is the order of their appearance?

The Treatise says that when the ten passions appear in sequence, ignorance appears first, because one is confused about the truths and does not want to contemplate suffering up to the truth of the path.
Because of not understanding, doubt is next produced, which means that having heard two sides, one is uncertain as to whether there is suffering or not, and so on.
From this doubt, wrong views are next produced, which means that having heard and contemplated wrongly, one forms a wrong determination and denies the truth of suffering, and so on.

Because of denying the truths, the view of a real self is next produced, which means that within the aggregates grasped, one denies the principle of suffering and is determined to grasp this as a self.
From this view of a real self, the extreme view is next produced, which means that based on grasping a self, one grasps either eternalism or annihilationism.
From this extreme view, the grasping of precepts and vows is next produced, which means that because one grasps either side in regard to a self, one then considers this grasping to be able to purify.

ASAVA means the three asavas:

OGHA means the four oghas:

YOGA means the four yogas, which are explained in the same way as the oghas.

First, the grasping of desire; second, the grasping of views; third, the grasping of precepts and observances; fourth, the grasping of self-doctrine.

The afflictions and entanglements of the desire realm, excluding delusion, are collectively called the contaminant of desire, referring to the thirty-one fundamental afflictions bound to the desire realm, along with the ten entanglements.

The afflictions of the form and formless realms, excluding delusion, are collectively called the fifty-two entities of the contaminated. This means that the fundamental afflictions of the two upper realms each have twenty-six.

The nature of the floods and bonds is the same as that of the asavas, but in addition to these, views are established separately as a flood and a bond. The flood and bond of desire are the asava of desire. The flood and bond of existence are the asava of existence.

The reason views are separated out and established as a flood and a bond is that they are sharp and intense and can cause one to remain in the cycle of rebirth. As will be explained later, they are called asavas because they can cause one to remain in the cycle of rebirth.

Views are not in accord with this, because their nature is sharp and intense. For this reason, they are not established separately as asavas, but can only be established as asavas in combination with other passions.
Thus it is shown that there are twenty-nine dharmas in the flood of desire, namely, the five kinds of craving, hatred, and pride, the four of doubt, and the ten envelopers.
There are twenty-eight dharmas in the flood of existence, namely, the ten of craving and pride, and the eight of doubt.
There are thirty-six dharmas in the flood of views, namely, the twelve views in each of the three realms.
Fifteen dharmas are called the flood of ignorance, that is, the five ignorances of the three realms.
You should know that the four yokes are the same as the floods, and the four clingings are the same as the four yokes.
However, desire and the view of a self each add ignorance, and the views are divided into two, which is different from the previous yokes.

The desire yoke and the desire ignorance of the previous are thirty-four dharmas in total, called the clinging of desire, namely, the five each of craving, hatred, pride, and ignorance, the four of doubt, and the ten entanglements.

The existence yoke and the two realm ignorances of the previous are thirty-eight dharmas in total, called the clinging of the view of a self, namely, the ten each of craving, pride, and ignorance, and the eight of doubt.

In the view yoke, excluding the clinging to mere rules and ritualism, the remaining thirty dharmas are called the clinging of views, and the six dharmas excluded are called the clinging to mere rules and ritualism.

Because it is able to grasp existence, grasping is established. However, because all ignorance is not able to grasp,
